data.title: Black Flag's My War & Math Rock, An Unlikely Beginning
data.meta_description: Album analysis of My War by Black Flag and its importance to the alternative music scene including the sub-genre math rock.
data.text:
Why Math Rock Needs to Thank Greg Ginn and Black Flag

Black Flag‘s My War is the band’s second full-length album, released in 1984. It marked a significant departure from their previous hardcore punk sound, incorporating slower tempos and heavier, more aggressive guitar riffs. The album is divided into two parts: the first half consists of shorter, faster tracks typical of their earlier work, while the second half features longer, brooding compositions. What’s cool is two of the songs on the second half of My War, “Three Nights” and “Scream,” hold moments of polyrhythmic percussion, a defining characteristic of math rock. Now, you might be wondering – what the f*ck is math rock? And why is the f*ck is this important?

What is Math Rock?

Math rock is a highly complex and rhythmically intricate style of rock music that is characterized by its atypical time signatures, irregular rhythms, and technical proficiency. The genre often features angular guitar riffs, unconventional chord progressions, and a strong emphasis on instrumental dexterity. Emerging in the late 1980s and gaining popularity in the 1990s, math rock has carved out a niche for itself within the broader alternative rock landscape. Bands such as Don Caballero, Slint, and Battles are often cited as influential within the math rock genre. Math rock continues to attract a devoted following due to its intellectual and avant-garde approach to rock music.

Album Analysis: Black Flag’s “My War”

And now back to Black Flag. Overall, and once again, My War, showcases a departure from their traditional hardcore punk sound, experimenting with heavier guitar tones, and more complex song structures. Tracks like “My War” and “Beat My Head Against the Wall” exemplify this shift, signaling the band’s willingness to push boundaries within the punk genre.

Thematically, My War presents a raw and introspective approach, addressing personal struggles, disillusionment, and societal critiques. The confrontational and sometimes bleak lyrics provide a stark contrast to the band’s earlier work, reflecting a deeper level of introspection.

Despite initial polarized reception, especially due to the love received for their first album Damaged, Black Flag‘s My War has since been recognized as a pioneering and influential album within the punk and alternative music scenes (including math rock). Its departure from convention challenged the boundaries of punk rock, inspiring a new wave of musical experimentation.

Why does any of this matter?

The album My War by Black Flag holds a revered status in the realm of math rock, a genre deeply influenced by its unconventional time signatures, dissonant guitar work, and intricate yet aggressive rhythm patterns. The significance of this influential album extends beyond its musical characteristics, as it embodies the raw energy and do-it-yourself ethos that resonates deeply with the independent and experimental spirit defining math rock.

The enduring legacy of My War continues to exert a profound influence on the sonic landscape of math rock, shaping its distinct sound and guiding the approach to songwriting within the genre. As math rock continues to evolve, the impact of Black Flag‘s My War remains a cornerstone of inspiration for countless bands and musicians, further solidifying its place in the fabric of the genre’s history.

AND to go even further about the band’s influence on math rock, Black Flag would later record, The Process of Weeding Out, which is considered to be one of the first math rock albums ever. All of which couldn’t have happened without this early exploration from the band. SO, when you see your math rock friends tell them – “you’re welcome.”
